awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Framework: Data: NSCI: HDR: GeoSCIFramework: Scalable Real-Time Streaming Analytics and Machine Learning for Geoscience and Hazards Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a real-time processing system capable of handling a large mix of sensor observations. The focus of this system is automation of the detection of natural hazard events using machine learning, as the events are occurring.  A four-organization collaboration (UNAVCO, University of Colorado, University of Oregon, and Rutgers University) develops a data framework for generalized real-time streaming analytics and machine learning for geoscience and hazards research.  This work will support rapid analysis and understanding of data associated with hazardous events (earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, tsunamis).  

This project uses a collaboration between computer scientists and geoscientists to develop a data framework for generalized real-time streaming analytics and machine learning for geoscience and hazards research.  It focuses on the aggregation and integration of a large number of data streams into a coherent system that supports analysis of the data streams in real-time. The framework will offer machine-learning-based tools designed to detect signals of events, such as earthquakes and tsunamis, that might only be detectable when looking at a broad selection of observational inputs.  The architecture sets up a fast data pipeline by combining a group of open source components that make big data applications viable and easier to develop. Data sources for the project draw primarily upon the 1500+ sensors from the EarthScope networks currently managed by UNAVCO and the Incorporated Research Institutions for Seismology (IRIS), as well as the Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) cabled array data managed by Rutgers University.  Machine learning (ML) algorithms will be researched and applied to the tsunami and earthquake use cases.  Initially, the project plans to employ an advanced convolutional neural network method in a multi-data environment.  The method has only been applied to seismic waveforms, so the project will explore extending the method to a multi-data environment.  The approach is expected to be extensible beyond detection and characterization of earthquakes to include the onset of other geophysical signals such as slow-slip events or magmatic intrusion, expanding the potential for new scientific discoveries.  The framework is applied to use cases in the Cascadia subduction zone and Yellowstone: these locations combine the expertise of the science team with locations where EarthScope and OOI have the greatest concentration of instruments.  The architecture will be transportable and scalable, running in a Docker environment on laptops, local clusters and the cloud.  Integral to the project will be development, documentation and training using collaborative online resources such as GitLab and Jupyter Notebooks, and utilizing NSF XSEDE resources to make larger datasets and computational resources more widely available.

This award by the NSF Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure is jointly supported by the Cross-Cutting Program and Division of Earth Sciences within the NSF Directorate for Geosciences, the Big Data Science and Engineering Program within the Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering, and the EarthCube Program jointly sponsored by the NSF Directorate for Geosciences and the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report

Understanding natural hazards such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions requires analyzing vast amounts of geophysical data collected from land, sea, and space. The GeoSCIFramework (GSF) project was designed to transform how scientists process and analyze this data by creating a powerful cyberinfrastructure that integrates real-time streaming data, machine learning, and cloud-based computing. This initiative was a collaboration among leading geoscience and data science institutions, including EarthScope Consortium, Rutgers University, the University of Colorado Boulder, and the University of Oregon, with additional computing support from XSEDE resources.

Advancing Scientific Discovery Through Data Innovation

One of the major achievements of GeoSCIFramework was developing a scalable and sustainable data framework that allows geoscientists and students to analyze petabyte-scale datasets. This system integrates real-time and archived data from a wide range of geophysical sensors, enabling advanced scientific studies on seismic activity, ground deformation, and ocean dynamics.

The project played a key role in enhancing early warning systems by applying machine learning techniques to detect earthquakes and tsunami-generating seismic events in real time. These algorithms improve our ability to recognize geophysical signals that precede hazardous events, making emergency alerts faster and more accurate.

Another important aspect of GSF was its ability to harmonize diverse geoscience datasets. Previously, researchers had to navigate multiple, often incompatible, data sources. This project developed standardized pipelines that integrate data from the NSF's GAGE and SAGE geophysical observatories, significantly improving accessibility and usability for the scientific community.

Transforming Infrastructure: Migration to Cloud Computing

A major outcome of the project was the successful migration of geophysical data archives to cloud computing platforms. The transition from aging on-premises systems to modern cloud-based services—such as those provided by Amazon Web Services (AWS)—brought enhanced security, greater scalability, lower costs, and improved performance for real-time data processing.

This shift has directly benefited operational hazard monitoring systems, including the USGS ShakeAlert Earthquake Early Warning System and NOAA’s Tsunami Warning System, by improving the efficiency and reliability of real-time data ingestion and analysis.

Applying Machine Learning to Hazard Monitoring

Machine learning played a crucial role in the project, enabling innovative applications such as:

  • Seismic Event Detection: A random forest machine learning model was trained to differentiate seismic activity from background noise, significantly improving detection accuracy.
  • Real-Time GNSS Position Monitoring: High-rate Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) data was integrated into machine learning pipelines to track ground motion with high precision.
  • Synthetic Earthquake Simulations: Researchers developed computational tools to generate “fakequakes,” which help refine earthquake early warning models.

These innovations are already being used in hazard monitoring systems and will continue to evolve, improving our ability to anticipate and mitigate the impacts of natural disasters.

Broadening Impact Through Education and Outreach

Beyond its scientific contributions, the GeoSCIFramework project actively supported training and education for students, researchers, and data scientists. The project developed a cloud-based educational environment called GeoLab, which hosts Jupyter Notebooks and interactive tools to teach big data processing, real-time analytics, and machine learning in geoscience.

The project also supported graduate research, resulting in multiple peer-reviewed publications and several Ph.D. theses focused on machine learning applications for earthquake early warning.

A Lasting Legacy

The outcomes of the GeoSCIFramework project extend far beyond its initial goals. By modernizing geophysical data infrastructure, advancing real-time analytics, and applying machine learning to hazard detection, the project has transformed the way geoscientists interact with big data. Its contributions will have a lasting impact on natural hazard research, early warning systems, and data-driven discovery in the geosciences.

The project’s innovations are now integrated into EarthScope’s core services, ensuring their long-term sustainability and continued evolution. As the scientific community builds on these advancements, the tools and frameworks developed under GeoSCIFramework will play a key role in protecting communities from natural hazards and deepening our understanding of Earth’s dynamic processes.
